												I played this game when it was released, and I was young and stupid so I died every couple of minutes and got frustrated. Re-installed it in 2006 and oh boy, what a joy it was !► The graphics don't matter here, it's a 2001 game so you can't expect much but you can set it to high resolutions. The good thing about its graphic engine it's the way in which both the enemies and your team can blend in a huge variety of environments. It is sometimes very hard to tell an enemy from a bush for instance, forcing the player to advance slowly, recon the area with the right team member, use the binoculars or the sniper before assaulting a given objective. Despite its age the game provides you with a great variety of environments starting with open woodlands under clear sky, cities, farming areas at night, snowy mountains, foggy marshes with low visiblity ahead and so on. And if that's not enough for you there's Desert Siege and Island Thunder , the game's two add-ons, adding desert environments ( DUH ) and treacherous jungles. This kind of variety is rarely seen in most tactical shooters , making Ghost Recon a must have for any player who likes the genre. ► The A.I is also great. You may experience some pathfinding problems with some of your squad members ( especially in closed environements such as houses - they sometimes get stuck behind a table or block your way upstairs, which is annoying but it doesn't happen that often , you may even finish the game without having these problems. But then again you can control any of your squad members and get them out of the way. ) The enemies have good reactions when a firefight starts, you will see them splitting up instead of sticking together like magnets or just married couples. They will try to get behind you, they advance a little, they stop for a few moments, they go right, they go left and you cannot predict the path they will take in order to find you and kill you. So hiding behind a rock and waiting for 20 russians to pop in one by one so you can shoot them is a no-no. Even in easy difficulty you'll find it challenging ( especially if it's your first time trying this game ).► Speaking of challenging, let me say a few words about something I didn't like in this game. You can save your games. Now it might sound stupid but save game options for this genre tend to ruin the experience a little bit. It is way more rewarding to finish a mission without saving your progress, it forces you to think twice before doing something, but if you fail 30 seconds before completing the last objective then it is very frustrating to start it all over again. Saving your progress is good for players who are new to tactical shooters, but the more experienced you get the less help you want to get from the game. And speaking about help, there's a radar at the bottom of the screen telling you if there are enemies around you. It doesn't tell you the number of enemies, the small circle turns red if you're approaching an enemy ( or being approached by it ). It also tells you from which direction the gunshots are coming, which is another small cheat. The problem with these tools is that they are distracting. I sometimes get shot because I spend half a second watching my radar to check the coming direction of the gunshots. Other than that, the HUD is alright, it shows your stance, level of injuries, remaining ammo and weapon used. The remaining ammunition in the magazines is another thing that should have been removed..► Overall the gameplay is good, simple but effective. You can bring up to six Ghosts to the battle, and assign them to Alpha, Bravo and Charlie squads. This gives room for nice pre-planning, you can therefore create a recon squad equiped with silenced weapons, an assault squad carrying assault rifles ( DUH ) and a sniper squad involving the sniper himself and a teamate to protect his back. This is one example among many you can use before pressing the start button. During the mission, you also have access to a tactical map, which is actually a very basic one offering you the possibility to adopt different behaviours ( Assault - fire at will /// Recon - Don't shoot /// and so on ) . You can assign waypoints to the teams allowing you to coordinate an assault for instance. But then again, careful with that tool, if the squad you're not controlling gets stuck behind a rock... there goes you planning. The map could have been greatly improved but it hasn't been, and that's a shame. Finally, the map menu also shows where your troopers have been injured. Being shot in the leg will make the Ghost move slower or will be forced to walk, whereas  an injured arm will greatly reduce his ability to shoot accurately. The objectives you have to complete stretch from capturing a high profile colonel ( and bring it back to the base - yes, you will have to go all the way back to the insertion area so pay attention more tangos incoming !! ) , blowing up planes, clearing an old castle's courtyard, assaulting a farm and a house, destroying tanks, rescuing NATO soldiers and so on and so forth. The diversity of Ghost Recon is amazing for such an old game !► It comes with 15 singleplayer missions , which is not that much but if you buy the add-ons you'll have enough for weeks . It also has a multiplayer, which I haven't tried, yet. You can also replay the missions, trying different approaches, using different squad members such as specialists ( you can unlock them by completing side objectives and they are very valuable squad members, they come with higher skills in every domain ( stealth, weapons, command, endurance ). You can upgrade the skills of each Ghost by assigning skill points, earned at the end of each mission. I recommend to upgrade the stealth skill as much as possible, I'm just saying... As a conclusion I would say that this is one of the best tactical shooters out there, and it comes at a cheap price ! What else do you need ?

ber 25, 2015
												Tom Clansy's owned Ghost Recon is a tactical shooter in which you get to control the squad during the mission itself while being able to take control of any of them. Yep, one of realistical tactical, where you die from one shot. It was developed by Red Storm and published in 2001, with being ported onto various consoles in following two years, that are Xbox, GameCube, PS2. And yes, it was made by same people as who made Rainbow Six few years ago, and now they were challenging players by moving action from close-range to long-range open combat. Just like Delta Force, but with fog. And squad tactics.And yes, it got two more expansion packs that you can buy on Steam as well.Technically, well, it's actually fine. Sure, game came out before widescreen monitors happened, but engine can support such resolution and allows you to select it from options. Main menu and such will stay as blocky low-resolution 4:3, but as soon as you get into gameplay, it will switch to what you set in options. FOV however will not increase, so people are still chubby.Not sure about multiplayer. Never got to playing it and Internet browser in the game itself appears as completely empty. No wind, no tumbleweeds. Perhaps server browser is broken. But as far as I am aware, it's dead. And multiplayer was the main positive point of this game, so we are left with less positive single-player.So, the plot is that in 2008 ultra-super-hyper-nationalists come to power in Russia and are now going to conquer and merge with countries that were part of USSR, starting with finding the way to take on Georgia. Funny how game predicted that in 2008 there will be conflict with Georgia and Russia, though it wasn't the one where Russia is your everyday demonized baddie. Anyway, you then go and take on various mission to kill people and do objectives, being world's judge. Until you beat final mission. And then get thrown into main menu immeditly. Because screw you, it's realistical tactical lack of ending!Graphics look kinda nice, I dig the enviroment for sure. Death animations do the job. Lack of gun in view is silly though. Music is fine, just randomly placed in main menu and then sometimes playes when somebody in your team dies.You got 15 single-players missions to complete and boy, it's not going to be easy. And it wasn't supposed to be easy. As fun as it could be. Anyway, you look at the map which doesn't tell you about verticality, then pick your platoon out of 6 members, that is divided into 3 squads, each having max to 3 people. Mind it, you can order only to whole squad, so better keep specialized people, like sniper, in separate special squad. And Demolition for enemy armor and mission objectives. And Support for having big magazine. But mostly riflemans. You can actually auto-assign people, and game handles it well, even though it never picks anybody from Specialist category. Who are powerful soldiers who may even have unique weapons.You can get Specialists by completing bonus objective. Where game can screw you up, because it ends mission as soon as either you done all main objective or if killed all enemies if last objective was moving to extraction point. That, and soldiers who died in battle will not reappear. At least they level up between each mission.And so you will run, you will walk, you will duck and crawl toward enemy, to get into position to shoot them all. Well, mostly running, otherwise you will run out of patience on these big maps covered in fog. And lean around. And notice threat indicator at the bottom of the screen showing red. And snipe enemies. Who will then run toward trees and hide and wait for a moment to lean around and put bulets into your dumb AI teammate. Who you will thankfully kill first. Until you realize that somebody threw grenade and you will be hopelessly trying to switch to each member and micro-manage them to run away. But they all die and so you restart mission as you don't want to have even less soldiers to pick in next mission.A thing to note, is the way that they did aiming thing. You see, unlike other games, the aiming will drop when you are turning around. Actually, turning around punishes you more than just walking slowly! As a result, it makes flanking more important in this game.With no planning phase for giving actual order, like in Rainbow Six, Ghost Recon lets you control team during gameplay. Just bring out the map, choose the squad, and click on a map, setting waypoint and where they are supposed to look. Then erase it and do it again, as map UI seems to be unreliably at selecting the team for some reason. But at least I prefer to be able to do it during gameplay. You can also set rules for each team, one for movement: Stop, Move but stop if being supressed, Move at any cost. And rule of engangement: Recon, shoot only if shot back, which is good for ordering troops to get into good position around enemy point. Assault, shoot accurately, sometimes, which is good when on the move and don't know where enemy is. And Supress, which makes them trigger-happy, good when you set them to defend or assault from one position.And well, now that you wonder what tactics there are, here is what to expect: Always come from unexpected side. If you need to assault inner building, then switch to soldier on one side, kill one enemy, switch to soldier on opposite side, kill another enemy and so on.As far squad tactics, well, they aren't reliable. But expect to use them to cover your flank. And sometimes to assault base while staying in one position. And moving people them around on map to get closer to objectives, so you could then control a soldier from squad, with others being like your "lives".Yep, AI teammates aren't reliable and soon you will feel divided. As it turns into mix of FPS action and Strategy game where you can't trust either part. Because sometimes AI can actually save you, but it's rare. Most often you will be wondering why your squad keeps being wiped out, then quickload and see person ignoring 9 sneaking soldiers, after all he is behind tree, he is INVINCIBLE!The fact that command map shows no verticality in level means you will have to manually position them anyway, often.Oh, and yes, I said quickload. Which means that there is quicksave. Which means that you can shove tactics into armor's rear and quickscam your way to the victory! No, really, Rainbow Six or Delta Force never allowed you to do it. But I guess that this cheapness counter-balances against the game's cheap difficulty where enemies can always aimbot you up. For knowledge is the main decision point in this game, and if you know what to expect, you don't need to crawl. You come in and kill all ten of them. Quickloading many times to get out from ambush.And let's be honest. Most of people who praise the game had it as the first game. And others who praise it do it because of how difficult it is. Mostly of how you can die randomly easily. And thus is somehow makes you feel better if you somehow manage to pull though. Not sure, I didn't feel anything like this, just a chore. Because well, when I died, I didn't feel that it was always fair, thus I just didn't care and reloaded a save.But I still can recommend the game. Well, not fully. Mostly above average. Because sometimes it works and makes you feel rewarded for positioning your team properly. Other times, it just screws you.Actually, when you just play some missions separately - it's a blast of trying to survive and setting good positions and tactics! Then there are some missions that feel messy and less fun. Look, stealth mission! It's just that main campaign, which makes me feel that I must be overprotective as it punishes you if your soldier dies by not having him in next missions, is where I just start to abuse quicksaves and grind it and get impatient.

												One of the first Tom Clancy titles that took FPS gameplay to the next level. I recommend this to everyone who seeks a challenging and strategic type of shooter. However it is recommended that beginners play the training mission first.In Ghost Recon you have to be careful before you take each step. It's like being a soldier in real life, where if you run out in the open you'll get spotted and shot within seconds. Enemies are often equipped with camo suits so they can hide themselves between trees, bushes and dirt. The same realism applies to the damage dealt by weapons, most of the time kills are achieved with 1 shot (except if you hit arms or legs).Although the game is based on levels, the map design makes it feel almost like a sandbox game. There are always many ways to complete the objectives. Not to mention that the quality of the foliage and nature environment is phenomenal for the date the game came out. There are also different classes and weapon sets that you can choose, which means variety in your playing style. In most games where you choose a class, you can only do that in multiplayer. You can also boost the stats of your soldiers after every mission, which in my opinion makes it a little more balanced because of the AI being challenging.Definitely recommended.

												** [[Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon]] **"Tactical" is a word many game publishers love to abuse for lacking first person shooters; Ghost Recon is not one of those games. Expect stellar gameplay with a variety of missions ranging from the jungle to the desert, weapons and customization. The campaign(s) are straight forward with a realistic approach focusing on establishing a democracy in a war-stricken land. The gameplay if a first-person shooter with a few HUD items along with a tactical map on which the player can direct his/her troops. Don't expect to get attached to the characters unless the player renames them after close companions in real life. There is a small skill tree on which the player can update units' skills including "Leadership", "Marksmanship", and more. Once the player's soldier dies in that campaign, they lose him and his skillset forever. There are a few classes to choose from with specialized weaponry corresponding to each class which makes each class valuable in its own respects. The multiplayer is dead, unless the player play it with a friend; unfortunantly, this is where the game shines. Strategizing on the map allows for dynamic gameplay; putting the player and their friends' minds together really makes the player feel as if the player is operating in a real spec ops mission. One of the downfalls to the gameplay has to be the difficulty, I recommend saving often with the "quick-save" and "quick-load" features; one wrong move can put a world of hurt on the player's team. Expect to run this game at a solid-locked 60FPS with ultra-high graphics. There is still a pretty decent modding community providing the player with extra campaign missions including a WWII campaign! Even though this game was made way back in 2000, it is still the most tactical game on my list. PROS:+ Solid Gameplay+ 60 FPS+ Variety of Mods+ Easy Integration of Mods+ Great Multiplayer With Friends+ Endless Hours of GameplayCons:- Brutal Difficulty- Dead Online Multiplayer

												War is hell, but if you're gonna do it, you gotta do it right. This game is as relevant and riveting today as it was when it first came out. It makes no bones about what it is: A pure tactical simulator, geared toward getting your team out alive and completing objectives from rescuing hostages to full-scale assault on armored patrols. My only gripe with this game is that, while it has good singleplayer, the AI of your team cannot often be trusted. Sending the computers into combat situations often results in friendly casualties, meaning it is best to take control of the squad you're sending into battle at one time. This is just my experience of course, but it does hamper you in that you cannot have two teams conquering two objectives at the same time.  However, they can act as sentries if placed right, and will defend points and shoot enemy soldiers with great accuracy, just not while they are on the move. Really though, this isn't a big issue, all it means is that the missions take a little longer, and even so, time flies when you are having fun! The AI of the enemies is very good, and they'll give you a bit of a bite even on recruit. This is not an arcade shooter, its a milsim on a tactical level. And I guarantee, if you take it as that, you're gonna have a helluva time.

												Ghost Recon is a realistic tactical shooter with squad control, similar to Rainbow Six Rogue Spear, but different in that it is more "play as you go" and depicts U.S. Army Special Forces fighting out in the open instead of the more methodical preplanned close quarters counter terrorist manuevers. I'll compare this to its rivals; "Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis" / "Arma: Cold war Assault" and "Delta Force: Land Warrior".This game costs around $10 without the two expansions, $20 with, and isn't on sale frequently. DF:LW has the same price, but includes more missions and a greater number of larger and more diverse maps. OFP/Arma ranges from $6 to free, goes on sale frequently, and has much larger maps that are fewer in number (though commmunity maps for ARMA outnumber GR's).GR controls are simpler, but more limiting than OFP/Arma and DF.GR total squad and fire team sizes are limited to six and three, respectively, while the OFP/Arma limit is twelve for each category and even has a high command module allowing for control of more. Squad control is less developed than OFP/Arma, but moreso than DF.GR's smaller numbers of vehicles and craft can't be entered or operated as in OFP/Arma, but they play more of a role than in DF.The GR tactical map is less informative, and there is no compass, watch, gps, or radio as there are in OFP/Arma.GR view and engagement distances are shorter, usually being within 130m (though fogless mod can extend that out to 500m). GR lacks the external ballistics effects of DF and OFP/Arma.Movement is more restricted in general, though GR allows one to lean whereas the others don't (without mods). Weaponry and munitions can't be picked up, and total selection is smaller.GR has wind effects, but no day/night or weather cycle like OFP/Arma.GR's AI can navigate tight spaces better than the others.Overall, Ghost Recon costs more and offers less, but looks slightly better and has a built in recorder and more detailed after action review.Additional content can be found on these sites : http://www.ghostrecon.net/ (get Enhanced Realism mod) http://www.moddb.com/games/tom-clancys-ghost-recon/downloads http://www.fileplanet.com/35386/0/section/Ghost-Reconhttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/realistictacticalgaming

												Still one of the most hardcore and tactical shooters. Runs with no issues on Windows 10.The graphics and sound still hold up well. The game is showing its age in areas from a gameplay perspective, but never in a way that greatly detracts from the experience provided you can adapt to some of the issues. For example, squad commands are limited and given from an overlay and you can't direct your squad to a position from the first-person view, which is a little clunky. In addition, your squad generally feels like a backup selection of playable characters that tag along with you as opposed to a group of AI you'll feel you can often use tactically and trust to perform without getting themselves killed.Other issues I had included the way the game occasionally cheap-shots you by spawning a tank or truck full of enemies out of nowhere, which rolls up to your position in complete silence; and whilst the large, open maps still feel unique and fun to play on, you can't climb or step down many hills or cliffs, which tends to limit your tactical ability.Still, as I said, none of this greatly detracts from the experience as it really never feels hugely misaligned with the gameplay--they're more just indications of the game's age. The atmosphere and intensity remains intact. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend a playthrough if you're into tactical shooters.

												This game, despite being very old to date, is actually quite the gem when it comes to gameplay. If you like a strategy FPS set up, well this will be your kind of game. You are given the option to create 3 squads for each mission, which can be given orders specific to that squad. The system used to further instruct the squads is based on "suppression", "assault", "reconnasiance", "advance at all costs", "advance", and "hold". This is very simple so that the player can easily control the AI's reaction to detecting enemies in the particular squad, but overall can make for an extremely dynamic scenario. in addition to squad orders, you can change between each individual in the squad or play multiplayer with friends to achieve the same goal.Every mission has a different goal and a different map, though i have found many of the goals to be the same type on consecutive missions, which made it feel grinding until you see the action of the game. Unfortunately the game also has a sort of "level" system for individual soldiers, which increases the feeling of grinding despite the fact that it's advantagous. Even with the previously stated feelings on the game, i found that overall Ghost Recon® was very fun especially to people who would love to see scenarios play out rather than directly get involved in them and vice versa for people who want to be in the scenario. In fact, the nature of this game's mechanics make it possible to both see how a scenario will play out and also have you be a major part in the scenario as well.Side Notes: missions typically take up to about 15-30 minutes, so if you're a casual player you'll be making alot of quick saves on the longer term missions (sometimes a whole hour)

												This game, despite being very old to date, is actually quite the gem when it comes to gameplay. If you like a strategy FPS set up, well this will be your kind of game. You are given the option to create 3 squads for each mission, which can be given orders specific to that squad. Unfortunately the game also has a sort of "level" system for individual soldiers, which increases the feeling of grinding despite the fact that it's advantagous. Even with the previously stated feelings on the game, i found that overall Ghost Recon® was very fun especially to people who would love to see scenarios play out rather than directly get involved in them and vice versa for people who want to be in the scenario. 												My thoughts on this great, old school and respectively 'simply' old tactical FPS-game. Unique in its scale, immersive and atmospheric, characterized by a realistic; 'one bullet/one kill' or, -depending on the perspective: 'one bullet/one death'-dynamic with an open-world approach to its first-person combat system what, I would say because of the nature of this game but a few games managed to portray it like this, in its "vanilla''; almost bare-bones: ''simple''-like form of approach.It's a game all right. Doesn't feel so much when you play it, which is sort of 'counter-intuitive' for a (casual) gamer, speaking as one. This game doesn't just resemble 'any' old-school shooter though for the experience is highly tactical, systematic, rooted in realistic aesthetics therefore perceived to be as such because there is just pure action here. It's like what I would imagine to be; stepping ''into'' VR for the first time. Captivation, immersion; beyond that to me subjectively this game (also) tells an engaging story.One could label the experience as ''adrenaline-filled'' military 'arcade-sim' on a simulated wide or large ''playing''-field or 'sandbox' - filled with set objectives and goals one has to accomplish and can so go about things in an 'asymmetrical' manner in which one does not stand alone. I think this game is well worked out to focus on that what is important and to incorporate in its execution ''only'' that which truly matters; very well. The game is all about the immersive action one takes part in.A Player is a part of - and is able to control - 3 squads within the play-field, with in-game real-time planning and execution phase where you as player can give (real-time) orders to your AI-controlled squad-mates through the means of a (GPS) map. Available orders comprise of a set of basic instructions that encompass all aspects that one would need in the field in order to command your squads to victory with only thing between you and the objectives: the enemy AI, which is feisty.This focus on where the priorities of the experience lie make the game excel in its simplicity. This simplicity doesn't make the game less challenging and is something that might not cater to casual FPS-players in the sense that the game takes the player by ''surprise'' presenting certain scale and depth to this simulated, virtual open-world combat that feels very grim, realistic; calculated & precise. It puts the player under pressure. Game is difficult in a sense, because it's relatively easy to take part in but hard to control as it is ultimately hard to master. In this sense I can say that, from experience; trial and error: 'savescumming' and 'restarting' often come to mind so there is a certain learning curve involved.Non the less this is a basic and somewhat simplistic (''minimalist'') shooter that has no gun model which was considered 'unusual' at the time of release (a perception I reckon hasn't changed much in the ''meanwhile'') but at heart is a well executed action-game with a certain amount of 90's charm infused within its essence. Game bares a Tom Clancy-title or name, after all; meaning: it has got a certain techno-thriller feel to it, which I like. (nostalgia)There is something about the game that gives quite a depth to the overall experience besides the nature of the game itself, which in its essence is pretty straightforward. I think that this is mostly contributed due to the storytelling (this aspect was more evident and prevelant, I think in previous iterations of the Rainbow Six series) but equal in part to the execution of the action phase which is very smooth.'Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon' is sort of a game that stands out as almost one of a kind shooter that excels in the sense of achievement, by being an 'open world' action-'sim' and having a realistic standard similar to what 'Rogue Spear' (and original Rainbow Six) achieved before it. There where the focus solely lied on the CQB-combat in Rainbow Six, this game takes that unforgiving style of gameplay to a 'wider-scale' of game-play.
